content.title: Endovascular Stenting
content.definition: Placement of a metallic mesh scaffold within an artery to maintain luminal patency after angioplasty, treat flow-limiting dissection, or provide structural support. Stents may be bare metal or drug-eluting, and self-expanding or balloon-expandable.

key_concepts.description: Balloon-expandable (BES): precise placement, high radial force, deforms if crushed; for aortoiliac, renal, carotid. Self-expanding (SES): nitinol memory metal, flexible, crush-resistant; for femoropopliteal, SFA, carotid
Metallic scaffold without drug coating; cheaper; higher restenosis rates; appropriate for large diameter, low-complexity lesions; aortoiliac disease
Stent with antiproliferative drug (paclitaxel or limus compounds) to reduce neointimal hyperplasia; lower restenosis than BMS; may require longer dual antiplatelet therapy
Stent with fabric covering (PTFE or Dacron); for aneurysm exclusion, perforation, or fistula; EVAR uses covered stents; also for traumatic vascular injuries
Primary stenting: aortoiliac disease, carotid (CAS), renal artery. Provisional stenting: suboptimal PTA result, flow-limiting dissection, elastic recoil
Primary: planned stent placement as initial treatment. Provisional: stent placed only if PTA result suboptimal. Different strategies for different arterial beds
DCB + provisional stenting now often preferred over primary stenting; self-expanding nitinol stents for flexibility; avoid stenting across knee if possible
Recurrent stenosis within previously placed stent; neointimal hyperplasia; treated with DCB, drug-eluting stent, or atherectomy
Break in stent struts due to mechanical stress (flexion, torsion); common in femoropopliteal; may lead to restenosis or occlusion; avoid stenting high-flexion zones
Size to reference vessel diameter or 1mm larger (SES); BES sized more precisely; oversizing causes vessel injury; undersizing causes migration/malapposition

content.statement: Endovascular Stenting is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Procedures Stenting that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding Endovascular Stenting helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of Endovascular Stenting include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of Endovascular Stenting.

definitions_glossary.concept: A fundamental idea or notion in the domain
definitions_glossary.property: A characteristic or attribute of an entity
definitions_glossary.relationship: A connection or association between concepts

learning_objectives: Know indications for primary vs provisional stenting
Understand in-stent restenosis and its treatment
Recognize stent fracture risk in femoropopliteal disease
clinical_pearls: DCB + provisional stenting now often preferred over primary SFA stent
Avoid stenting across the knee (fracture risk)
In-stent restenosis treated with DCB or drug-eluting stent
Covered stent for perforation = bailout device
common_mistakes: Using balloon-expandable in SFA (crushes with knee flexion)
Primary stenting when DCB alone would suffice
Not recognizing stent fracture as cause of recurrent symptoms

sources.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.
